Award.AwardTitle: Socially Networked Autonomy: How Should Machines Interact With Society?

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies decision design methodologies for autonomous agents that are networked with and interacting among human beings in societal systems. The running application example is that of an urban highway network in which a portion of the vehicles are autonomously operated. The core question is this: how should a system planner design the routing policies of the autonomous vehicles to have the greatest positive impact on overall network traffic congestion, even if human drivers react in a self-interested way to the behavior of the autonomous vehicles? Intuitively, it would appear beneficial to design the autonomous vehicles to be altruistic; that is, to select highway routes that cause the least congestion to other drivers. However, recent work shows that this simple and intuitive routing design policy may backfire, leading to a cascade of behaviors which inadvertently worsens congestion. This project will investigate how a designer can circumvent these pathologies through the design of smart routing policies. One of the key questions this project will address is how selfish should autonomous vehicles be? This project includes public outreach to help members of the public discern between good and bad modes of influence in socially networked autonomous systems. In addition, it will provide a theoretical framework for engineering practitioners to certify that the interactive aspects of smart systems have been designed to provide broad societal benefits in a principled way.

This project addresses fundamental behavior design questions for socially-networked multiagent systems; an intrinsic feature of this problem is that overall system performance is governed not only by the designable behavior of the autonomous agents, but also on the self-interested behavior of human participants. The element of interactive optimization places this project squarely in the domain of game theory, and the investigators adapt popular congestion game models to study these questions in the context of smart autonomous vehicle routing in highway networks. A fleet of autonomous vehicles is modeled as a discrete player in a continuous-player-set network congestion game; the project studies how routing policies for the autonomous vehicles impact the game-theoretic equilibria of the overall system. This allows the investigators to model, in a principled way, the interactions between designed agents (i.e., autonomous vehicles) and selfish agents (i.e., human drivers). Ultimately, the investigators seek a comprehensive understanding of how and when autonomous vehicles should be endowed with various routing policies. This project advances knowledge in two distinct dimensions: first, it provides an in-depth case study examining the opportunities and limitations of the use of connected autonomous vehicles for influencing traffic routing in transportation networks. Second, and more broadly, it will provide the foundations for an underlying theory of social influence in smart and connected cyber-physical systems. As smart cyber-physical devices are increasingly integrated into public life, it is critical that these smart devices are designed to interact with and influence human behavior in ways that are effective, efficient, and principled â€“ and this project represents a central pillar of this endeavor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project's goal was to understand and mitigate pathological effects arising from the interactions between human and machine decision-making, specifically in the context of smart routing policy design for connected autonomous vehicles. A core concept in this project is an "altruistic" decisionmaker, defined as one which attempts to individually optimize some system-level objective. We investigated a class of "altruism paradoxes" in which increasing the fraction of altruistic decisionmakers inadvertently leads to degraded system-level performance. Considering this known pathology, the project sought principled and proactive techniques for mitigating its harm.

Intellectual merit: This project's results represent a substantial leap in our understanding of the role of altruistic routing policies in smart transportation networks. Our primary research effort has solved two substantial open questions: (1) how altruistic should self-driving cars be (optimally weighing the potential costs with the potential benefits), and (2) how does the structure of the underlying transportation network affect the benefits and harms of altruistic routing?

On the first question, we discovered that "a little bit of altruism goes a long way." It has long been known that altruism confers huge benefits when most of the decisionmakers are altruistic, but that mixing selfish with altruistic decisionmakers can result in worse outcomes than if all decisionmakers were simply selfish. Our new findings indicate that altruism has its biggest benefits in the initial transition from selfishness to altruism, but that making cars more altruistic has steeply diminishing returns. Accordingly, by programming self-driving cars to be slightly more altruistic than the surrounding human drivers, a system designer can obtain significant benefits while avoiding most of the harm which altruism can cause.

On the second question, our findings gave comprehensive answers and essentially solved the problem in its entirety. It has long been known that a certain class of networks called "series-parallel" networks are immune to a variety of paradoxical and pathological behaviors in routing problems. In fact, the initial proposal for this project conjectured that series-parallel networks were also immune to "altruism paradoxes," in the sense that making drivers more altruistic on any series-parallel highway network always improves traffic congestion on that network. Our research results comprehensively confirmed this conjecture; we showed that if 3 conditions all hold on a network: (a) the network is series-parallel, (b) all drivers can access all network paths, and (c) all network paths satisfy a "reasonableness" criterion, then altruism can never cause harm on that network relative to selfishness. In addition, we show that these conditions are sharp: if a network fails any one of those 3 conditions, then it is possible to choose congestion parameters for that network for which partial altruism is strictly harmful.

In addition to these core scientific questions, research activities sponsored by this project made several other important discoveries as well on topics ranging from the stability of equilibria in competitive resource allocation, altruism in large populations of interacting agents, altruism in lane-changing behaviors in highways, and monetary incentive design for highway networks.

Broader Impacts: As part of this project, the PI gave several public lectures to lay audiences in an effort to disseminate the research approach and results more broadly. These lectures were very well received, and covered topics such as the impact of autonomous altruism and the ethics of self-driving cars. Several students at UCCS were funded in whole or in part by this project; in particular, 2 PhD students and 2 undergraduate researchers received a substantial portion of the project's budget.

In addition, the PI has applied concepts from this research project to assist a local small business with their aircraft routing and weather intelligence software tools. Fundamentally, the similarities between aircraft routing and ground vehicle routing allowed the PI to contribute intellectually to the development of weather-aware aircraft routing software.

Furthermore, the PI teaches upper-level elective courses in the Computer Science department at UCCS and regularly integrates advanced concepts from this research project into these courses. These courses cover game theory and social networks, and help give computer science students a foundation for responsible engineering practices in the context of socially-integrated engineered systems (such as social media applications, smart infrastructure, and the internet-of-things).
